20230001.title: NHS 111 Cyber-attack Outage
20230001.description: The National Health Service (NHS) 111 service, which provides U.K. citizens with 24/7 medical consultation services, suffered a system outage as a result of a ransomware attack against a contractor. The contractor, called Advance, provided approximately 85% of NHS's systems, which were used to dispatch ambulances, manage patient records, and handle emergency prescriptions (among other things). The attack resulted in significant outages and delays across the 111 service for several days.

20230002.title: Suffolk County Ransomware Attack
20230002.description: The Suffolk County, NY clerk's office was compromised by the ALPHV group in December, 2021 through exploitation of the Log4j vulnerability. The attackers then spent eight months installing bitcoin mining software, establishing persistence, and creating fake accounts. In August, 2022, the group was able to escalate their attack through obtained credentials, gaining access to other Suffolk County departments before deploying BlackCat ransomware across the compromised systems. This resulted in 911 dispatchers using pen and paper, rather than their digital CAD system, and law enforcement officers calling in crime scene information via radio, rather than using their tablet-based emails. It also resulted in a months-long website outage for the entire county.

20230003.title: CommonSpirit Health Ransomware Attack
20230003.description: A ransomware attack against CommonSpirit Health resulted in disruptions across their hospitals spanning 21 states. These disruptions were felt particularly in midwestern states like Iowa and Indiana, resulting in ambulance diversions, cancelled appointments, and even a misdose of a patient. In terms of diversions, 5 ambulances were diverted from Iowa's MercyOne Des Moines Medical Center to UnityPoint Health-Des Moines.

20230004.title: MedStar Ambulance Ransomware Attack
20230004.description: MedStar Ambulance was compromised by attackers who gained unauthorized access to a number of files, potentially affecting 612,000 people. The perpetrators then deployed ransomware, causing an impact on MedStar Ambulance's CAD and patient record systems. 911 systems were reported to not have been impacted, but personnel reportedly used manual radios for dispatching due to concerns of system confidentiality and integrity; this was said to create a delay in ambulance response times.

20230005.title: Empress EMS Ransomware Attack
20230005.description: Empress EMS, a company that provides ambulance service to communities throughout New York, was infiltrated by attackers. After a few months, the responsible actors exfiltrated a "small subset" of files before deploying ransomware across systems. 318,558 patients were reported to have been impacted.

20230006.title: Comstar Data Breach
20230006.description: Comstar, an ambulance billing company, observed suspicious network behavior in March, 2022. Upon further investigation, they realized that an unauthorized party had gained access to patient records. Comstar did not observe the breach occuring in real-time, but determined post factum that up to 69,000 individuals were affected.

20230007.title: Erie County TDoS Incident
20230007.description: On October 23rd, 2022, at 8:55pm, the Erie County, PA 911 center began to receive a high volume of calls originating from a single "deactived wireless device". This resulted in the 911 center becoming overwhelmed and some legitimate callers suffering from delays. The perpetrator and motivation remain unknown. The issue was mitigated through expansion of existing NG911 infrastructure, including isolation of the faulting device and creation of additional phone trunks for dispatchers.

20230008.title: CLOP Leaks UK Police Data
20230008.description: In October, 2021, the IT firm 'Dacoll' suffered a hack by the CL0P ransomware gang. This resulted in encryption of their data and exfiltration of a number of sensitive files. In December, 2021, it became apparent that this included limited information from the U.K. Police, including images from the country's Automatic Numberplate Recognition, was for sale on the Dark Web. While the sellers indicated that it was from the Police National Computer (PNC), U.K. Police denied that any of their systems had been compromised.

20230009.title: Fire-Rescue Victoria Ransomware
20230009.description: In December, 2022, Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV) suffered a ransomware attack at the hands of Vice Society. That attack resulted in the disclosure of sensitive data regarding current and former employees; the breached data also potentially included former applicants to FRV. Additionally, Vice Society took down FRV's email system while accessing sensitve data, causing a longer-lasting disruption to services within the department. Disruption also negatively impacted the department's CAD system, causing units to be dispatched manually via phone and radio instead.

20230010.title: City of Oakland Ransomware Attack
20230010.description: The City of Oakland declared a local state of emergency in response to a ransomware attack in February, 2023. The city stated that emergency services were not impacted, but the Oakland Police Department sent a tweet indicating that response times were delayed as a result. The primary impact of the attack was encryption and exfiltration of personnel files from the municipality, which were later identified for sale on the Dark Web. The attack was determined to be the work of the Play Ransomware group

20230011.title: CHU Saint-Pierre Diverts Ambulances
20230011.description: In March, 2023, CHU Saint-Pierre, a Belgian hospital, suffered an unspecified "cyber attack". It was later reported that the attack was a computer virus, which had resulted in the hospital shutting down its infrastructure to preemptively prevent propagation. As a direct result of the attack, ambulances were diverted for several hours to prevent the hospital's resources from becoming overwhelmed.

20230012.title: Dallas Police Department Struck by Ransomware
20230012.description: In the early morning hours of May 3rd, 2023, the city of Dallas, Texas was struck by a ransomware attack. While it's unclear exactly what caused the attack to occur, the impact on emergency services was quickly obvious. It forced both law enforcement and fire-rescue to revert to manual dispatching mechanisms, with indications that their computer aided dispatch (CAD) systems had been taken offline. While 911 calls themselves weren't impacted, Dallas PD also indicated that internal shared drives and personnel records had also been affected. Dallas Fire-Rescue described how they were using coordination via public safety radio and public maps apps to overcome their loss of technology.

20230013.title: Scripps Healthcare Ransomware Attack
20230013.description: On May 1st, 2021, Scripps Healthcare was struck by a ransomware attack. It caused the cancellation of appointments, loss of patient records, and diversion of ambulances. Those ambulance diversions caused increased transport times and wall-holding among EMS personnel, in addition to straining nearby hospitals by pushing all new patients on to them.

media.name: Journal of the American Medical Association

20230014.title: City of Lowell Ransomware Attack
20230014.description: On April 24th, 2023, the Play ransomware group compromised the network for the city of Lowell, MA. They soon exfiltrated and encrypted data, resulting in disruptions for servers and telephone systems. While Lowell never published many details to the public about the attack, it's known that the attack impacted systems for Lowell's police and fire departments, although 911 was never disrupted. The Play group initially released 5 GB of stolen data on their website, but no news articles were published announcing any further disclosures. While unconfirmed, that may be indicative of a ransom payment.

20230015.title: City of Augusta Ransomware Attack
20230015.description: The City of Augusta, Georgia disclosed that they had suffered an outage starting September 21st, 2023 that was determined to be the result of an ongoing cyber-attack. Specifically, the city's systems were infected by BlackByte ransomware. While not officially disclosed, BlackByte placed at least 10 GB of stolen Augusta data on their Tor site. The ransomware was found to affect the CAD system that permitted data sharing between 911 and responders, forcing dispatchers to resort to a 'manual' system.

20230016.title: Idaho Hospital Forced to Divert Ambulances
20230016.description: Idaho Falls Community Hospital was struck by a virus that infected a number of its systems. While hospital IT staff were able to disconnect systems before it spread too far, the disruption of emergency room equipment caused the hospital to go on diversion and redirect any responding ambulances elsewhere. Idaho Falls Community Hospital staff refused to acknowledge whether or not the event was the result of ransomware, indicating only that it was some form of 'virus'.

20230017.title: Swatting of Ubisoft Montreal
20230017.description: On November 13th, 2020, Yanni Ouahioune contacted police to report that multiple hostages had been taken in Ubisoft's Montreal office. This prompted the response of a tactical police unit, which entered the building and eventually determined the report to be false. Ouahioune had placed the call due to being banned from Ubisoft's game 'Rainbow Six Siege' multiple times, inducing anger towards the company. Three years later he was caught and sentenced to three years of community service.

20230018.title: Swatting in Wichita, Kansas
20230018.description: Police were dispatched to a residential home on November 13th, 2017 for reports of a man who had shot his father and was holding multiple people hostage. Upon police arrival, an officer killed a man who arrived at the front door of the residence. It was later determined that no one else was injured and that the call was an instance of swatting. The perpetrator was caught two years later and charged with making a false report that resulted in a death, eventually being sentenced to 20 years in prison. It was discovered that the swatting incident had been the result of a dispute between Barriss and the victim over a $1.50 bet in Call of Duty.

20230019.title: City of Hayward Ransomware Attack
20230019.description: On Sunday, July 28th, 2023, the City of Hayward detected a ransomware attack on their network. The city preemptively shut down its website on Monday. Hayward reported no signs that any personal information had been compromised. While the emergency services were said to have not had their ability to respond impacted, it was later reported that the ransomware had impacted the CAD system, making it more difficult to appropriately respond to or coordinate calls for help.

20230020.title: Swatting in Knoxville, Tennessee
20230020.description: Police were sent to a residential home for a report from a suicide hotline that a subject inside had already killed a 4-year-old child. Upon arrival, officers spoke to the homeowner and realized that the call was fabricated, which was confirmed following a sweep of the house.

20230021.title: Swatting in Leitchfield, Kentucky
20230021.description: Leitchfield PD and FD were dispatched for reports of a male who had shot his wife, tied up another man, and was threatening to burn down the house. The caller also stated that there were children inside. The large law enforcement response realized soon after arrival that the call was fake.

20230022.title: Swatting in Orchard Park, NY
20230022.description: On July 9th, two repairmen were working on a house when police arrived. They stated that they had received a call reporting four black men who had tied up a man inside the house. This was quickly proven to be false, and most articles have cited the fact that this was likely racially motivated.

20230023.title: ePCR Cyber-attack Impacts NHS Ambulance Trusts
